abstract.para: This package contains pebble count data and analysis for the Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) program, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, WA. Wolman pebble counts were measured at each of the (3) cross sections for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Cleaned raw data, summarized data, and graphs are included in the package.
For more detailed information on the LTAM program, refer to the LTAM Methods and Reports package.

description.para: The methods for collecting pebble count data are based on the Wolman Pebble count method. The b-axis, or medium axis, of the sediment particle to the nearest mm is measured using a see-through ruler. Make sure the markings on the ruler have not rubbed off and are very clear. For measurements less than 2 mm, record 1. Do not assume a particle is less than 2 mm without measuring it first. Each axis (a, b, and c) are perpendicular to each other. It is usually easiest to find the c-axis, or long axis, then work in a perpendicular fashion to find the a-axis, or short axis, and finally the b-axis. Sometimes two axes are very similar which will require measuring both axes to determine which one is the b-axis. Choose each particle in a systematic and random fashion for the entire transect, which is usually a blind touch with the forefinger off the tip of your boot. If your blind touch results in touching fine sediment on top of larger rocks, the fine sediment is what is measured as it was the first particle that came into contact with your finger. The pace must be consistent for the entire transect although pace can be different between transects. A transect must be finished regardless if the desired goal is met mid-transect.

The methods for summarizing pebble count data are based on minor adjustments to the USDA Forest Service Pebble Count Analyzer (2007) and include particle size class cumulative distribution and histogram results, particle size in mm at the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles, and p-value significance for the particle sizes of 2 mm, 4 mm, 8 mm, and 16 mm.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: This data is part of a long-term stream research program to measure the overall ecological response of the watershed to HCP management activities and to monitor stream health, document recovery from past water supply and land management operations, evaluate the success of stream habitat restoration projects, and help to identify any impacts of the City’s operations on stream ecosystems.

award.funderName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities
award.title: Long-term Stream Monitoring

dataTable.entityDescription: Wolman Pebble count data, including individual measurements and particle sizes at the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles, for each of the (3) cross sections at all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Each particle was measured in mm. If less than 2 mm, 1 was recorded and included in analysis. If bedrock was encountered, 999 was recorded and excluded from analysis. Percentiles are based on the Excel PERCENTILE function.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Analysis Data Table Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of an analysis data table.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.

Year Site XS ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year, Site No, "<DECIMAL>", and Cross Section No. For example, 20062.1 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, Cross Section 1, and 201022.3 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22, Cross Section 3.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
User Name, as downloaded from Pendragon Forms or other electronic form. Also, "999" refers to not applicable; and "-999" refers to data that is required but is missing.
Timestamp, Date or Date and Time for when the data was collected and in format MM/DD/YYY hh:mm:ss.
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.
The names or initials of each person who participated in the survey.
Cross Section No., A number that identifies the cross section, whereas the cross sections are typically (but not always) numbered sequentially starting from the most downstream end of the site.
A description of number and types of channels present at the pebble count location, ie. “main ch”, “side ch”, “other”, etc.

The number of particles per record counted for a particular cross section or location. There might be more than one record per cross section if the data was collected on different days or if there were two recorders.
Comments, free form text for interesting or unusual sightings, problems, or issues.

Cross Section d16 Per Year Site XS Identifier and using PERCENTILE, where d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 16% of the particles are smaller, PERCENTILE refers to the Excel function PERCENTILE, and Year Site XS Identifier is for a particular cross section, site, and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than d16 from a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d16 is an important size class in streams because it helps characterize the fine sediment load and is used as a ratio with d84 to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Cross Section d50 Per Year Site XS Identifier and using PERCENTILE, where d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 50% of the particles are smaller, PERCENTILE refers to the Excel function PERCENTILE, and Year Site XS Identifier is for a particular cross section, site, and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than d16 from a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d50 is an important size class in streams because it is used in many formulas to determine critical sheer stress and to predict the onset of scouring.

Cross Section d84 Per Year Site XS Identifier and using PERCENTILE, where d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 84% of the particles are smaller, PERCENTILE refers to the Excel function PERCENTILE, and Year Site XS Identifier is for a particular cross section, site, and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than d16 from a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d84 is an important size class in streams because it is often used in stability analysis to estimate resistance and hydraulic roughness.

Cross Section d84 and d16 Ratio Per Year Site Identifier, whereas the ratio is calculated via D84/D16 for a particular cross section, site, and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account to differences at the cross section scale. The d84 to d16 ratio is an important metric in streams because it helps to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Average of Cross Section d84 and d16 Ratios Per Year Site Identifier, whereas the ratio is calculated by averaging the cross section d84/d16 ratios for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. The d84 to d16 ratio is an important metric in streams because it helps to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Ave of Cross Section d16 Results Per Year Site Identifier, whereas the average is calculated by averaging the cross section d50 results for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. d16 is an important size class in streams because it helps characterize the fine sediment load and is used as a ratio with d84 to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Ave of Cross Section d50 Results Per Year Site Identifier, whereas the average is calculated by averaging the cross section d50 results for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. d50 is an important size class in streams because it is used in many formulas to determine critical sheer stress and to predict the onset of scouring.

Ave of Cross Section d84 Results Per Year Site Identifier, whereas the average is calculated by averaging the cross section d84 results for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to account for differences at the cross section scale. d84 is an important size class in streams because it is often used in stability analysis to estimate resistance and hydraulic roughness.

Reach d16 Per Year Site Identifier and using PERCENTILE, where d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 16% of the particles are smaller, PERCENTILE refers to the Excel function PERCENTILE, and Year Site Identifier is for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to lump all particles at the reach scale and not needing to account for differences at the finer cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d16 is an important size class in streams because it helps characterize the fine sediment load and is used as a ratio with d84 to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Reach d50 Per Year Site Identifier and using PERCENTILE, where d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 50% of the particles are smaller, PERCENTILE refers to the Excel function PERCENTILE, and Year Site Identifier is for a particular site and survey year. Use this attribute when wanting to lump all particles at the reach scale and not needing to account for differences at the finer cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d50 is an important size class in streams because it is used in many formulas to determine critical sheer stress and to predict the onset of scouring.

Use this attribute when wanting to lump all particles at the reach scale and not needing to account for differences at the finer cross section scale. PERCENTILE yields a slightly different result than a particle size histogram due to an exact value (PERCENTILE) vs an average in the distribution (particle size histogram). PERCENTILE can be used to double check particle size histogram results. d84 is an important size class in streams because it is often used in stability analysis to estimate resistance and hydraulic roughness.

The d84 to d16 ratio is an important metric in streams because it helps to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

Pebble B-Axis Length (mm) of Particle 1. The b-axis (medium axis) of the sediment particle is measured to the nearest mm using a see-through ruler. Make sure the markings on the ruler have not rubbed off and are very clear (if a ruler is kept in the backpack all field season some of the markings will have rubbed off by the end of the field season). For measurements < 2 mm record "1". Do not assume a particle is < 2 mm without measuring it first. Each axis (a, b, and c) are perpendicular to each other. It is usually easiest to find the c-axis (long axis) then work in a perpendicular fashion to find the a-axis (short axis) and finally the b-axis. Sometimes two axes are very similar which will require measuring both axes to determine which one is the b-axis. Choose each particle in a systematic and random fashion for the entire transect (usually a blind touch with the forefinger off the tip of your boot). The pace must be consistent for the entire transect although pace can be different between transects. A transect must be finished regardless if the desired goal is met mid-transect.

Make sure the markings on the ruler have not rubbed off and are very clear (if a ruler is kept in the backpack all field season some of the markings will have rubbed off by the end of the field season). For measurements < 2 mm record "1". Do not assume a particle is < 2 mm without measuring it first. Each axis (a, b, and c) are perpendicular to each other. It is usually easiest to find the c-axis (long axis) then work in a perpendicular fashion to find the a-axis (short axis) and finally the b-axis. Sometimes two axes are very similar which will require measuring both axes to determine which one is the b-axis. Choose each particle in a systematic and random fashion for the entire transect (usually a blind touch with the forefinger off the tip of your boot). Make sure the markings on the ruler have not rubbed off and are very clear (if a ruler is kept in the backpack all field season some of the markings will have rubbed off by the end of the field season). For measurements < 2 mm record "1". Do not assume a particle is < 2 mm without measuring it first. Each axis (a, b, and c) are perpendicular to each other. It is usually easiest to find the c-axis (long axis) then work in a perpendicular fashion to find the a-axis (short axis) and finally the b-axis. Sometimes two axes are very similar which will require measuring both axes to determine which one is the b-axis. Choose each particle in a systematic and random fashion for the entire transect (usually a blind touch with the forefinger off the tip of your boot). The pace must be consistent for the entire transect although pace can be different between transects. A transect must be finished regardless if the desired goal is met mid-transect.

Pebble B-Axis Length (mm) of Particle 173. The b-axis (medium axis) of the sediment particle is measured to the nearest mm using a see-through ruler. Make sure the markings on the ruler have not rubbed off and are very clear (if a ruler is kept in the backpack all field season some of the markings will have rubbed off by the end of the field season). For measurements < 2 mm record "1". Do not assume a particle is < 2 mm without measuring it first. Each axis (a, b, and c) are perpendicular to each other. dataTable.entityDescription: Pebble Count cumulative particle size class distribution and histogram data, including particle sizes at the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles, as summarized from Wolman pebble counts at each of the (3) cross sections for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. The size class ranges and descriptions are based on the USDA Forest Service Pebble Count Analyzer (2007). Analysis includes assumptions for the smallest and largest size classes, where for particles less than 2 mm, 1 was used, and bedrock was excluded in the analysis. Sizes at the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles were calculated by manually entering the largest size that yielded a percentile of just less than the 16th, 50th, and 84th percentiles, where percentiles were based on counts in the size classes.

Year Site XS ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year, Site No, "<DECIMAL>", and Cross Section No. For example, 20062.1 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, Cross Section 1, and 201022.3 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22, Cross Section 3.

(d16) mm From Histogram, whereas d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 16% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram. d16 is an important size class in streams because it helps characterize the fine sediment load and is used as a ratio with d84 to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

(d16) mm From Histogram Class Name, whereas class name describes particle size classes (gravel, boulder, etc) and d16 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 16% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram. d16 is an important size class in streams because it helps characterize the fine sediment load and is used as a ratio with d84 to characterize sediment sorting (i.e., a high ratio could indicate poor sorting).

(d50) mm From Histogram, whereas d50 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 50% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram. d50 is an important size class in streams because it is used in many formulas to determine critical sheer stress and to predict the onset of scouring.

(d50) mm From Histogram Class Name, whereas class name describes particle size classes (gravel, boulder, etc) and d50 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 50% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram. d50 is an important size class in streams because it is used in many formulas to determine critical sheer stress and to predict the onset of scouring.

(d84) mm From Histogram, whereas d84 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 84% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram. d84 is an important size class in streams because it is often used in stability analysis to estimate resistance and hydraulic roughness.

(d84) mm From Histogram Class Name, whereas class name describes particle size classes (gravel, boulder, etc) and d84 refers to the particle size in (mm) in which 84% of the particles are smaller in a particle size histogram.

dataTable.entityDescription: Pebble Count statistical p-value analysis at 0.05 alpha for fine sediments as summarized from Wolman pebble counts at each of the (3) cross sections for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Four sediment sizes were analyzed, 2 mm, 4 mm, 8 mm, and 16 mm. Most of this analysis is based on or cross checked with the USDA Forest Service Pebble Count Analyzer (2007) and is referenced as such in the data table. Analysis includes assumptions for the smallest and largest size classes, where for particles less than 2 mm, 1 was used, and bedrock was excluded in the analysis.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Cross Section No., A number that identifies the cross section, whereas the cross sections are typically (but not always) numbered sequentially starting from the most downstream end of the site.

Year Site XS ID or Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data, whereas if the data summary refers to cross section data, it is a conjugate of Year, Site, XS ID which is the 4 digit Sample Year, Site No, "<DECIMAL>", and Cross Section No; or if the data summary refers to the reach scale, it is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No (and no decimal).

Total No. Particles for pebble count

Reference Year, the sample year of a dataset where the dataset represents the ideal or stable condition (ie. the measure in which to compare "from"). In repeat monitoring surveys where environmentally friendly management practices are employed, it is typically the most recent sample year as it's expected that conditions will improve over time. Loaded as 4 digit number and not a date format.

Study Year, the sample year of a dataset where the dataset represents unknown conditions that need evaluation (ie. the measure in which to compare "to"). In repeat monitoring surveys where environmentally friendly management practices are employed, it is typically the first sample year or a prior sample year as it's likely conditions were less stable in prior years. Loaded as 4 digit number and not a date format.

Test (1) Criterion (mm), whereas the criterion is the particle size in (mm) in which to perform a 2 sample proportion test. In pebble counts, the 2 samples could be pebble counts at the same location but from different survey years, from a study reach and a reference reach, or before and after installing a restoration project. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) Tails, whereas a 1-tailed test focuses on detecting a difference in a specific direction (e.g., greater than or less than) and a two-tailed test checks for any difference, regardless of direction (e.g., not equal to). A 1-sample t-test compares a single sample's mean to a known value, and a 2-sample t-test compares the means of two independent groups. In cumulative effects analysis such as in pebble counts, a uni-directional (or one-tailed) test can be appropriate for whether the sample reach is greater than the reference reach (Ps > Pr). For example did a management action increase the fine sediment proportion of the particle size distribution? 1-tailed, uni-directional tests are more sensitive than 2-tailed, two-directional tests but do carry the danger of ignoring significant change in the opposite direction. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) Alpha, whereas Alpha is the significance level and represents the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true, a Type 1 error (ie, a false positive, or the probability of observing a difference due to chance, or falsely concluding that there is a significant effect or difference when, actually, there is no difference). It is often set to 0.05 (ie, 5%). Alpha is related to the confidence level, which is 1 - α. For example, if Alpha α = 0.05, the confidence level is 95% (1 - 0.05 = 0.95). For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) P-value (Real-stats), whereas P-value is the probability value, is between 0 and 1, and describes the likelihood an observed difference could have occurred under the null hypothesis, and Real-stats is in an Excel-add in that extends the built-in statistical capabilitie,s with supplemental functions and analysis tools. The null hypothesis in sediment analysis is that any observed difference of particles smaller than the criterion in (mm) is due to random chance, and there is no real underlying difference in the sediment composition. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) P-value (Real-stats) Significance, whereas the choice is YES or NO as to whether there is statistical significance as derived from the Excel Real-stats add-in, and significance is inversely proportional to the P-value (ie, 1 - P-value). YES affirms P-value < Alpha and is therefore significantly different (ie,. the likelihood that an observed difference is a real effect and not due to random chance, or the likelihood that the particle size threshold in (mm) is significantly different between survey years), and NO affirms is P-value >= Alpha and is therefore not significantly different. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) P-value (USFS), whereas P-value is the probability value, is between 0 and 1, and describes the likelihood an observed difference could have occurred under the null hypothesis, and USFS is the P-value result using the USFS Size Class Pebble Count Analyzer (2007) and is a 1-tailed test. The null hypothesis in sediment analysis is that any observed difference of particles smaller than the criterion in (mm) is due to random chance, and there is no real underlying difference in the sediment composition. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (1) P-value (USFS) Significance, whereas the choice is YES or NO as to whether there is statistical significance as derived from the USFS Size Class Pebble Count Analyzer (2007) and is a 1-tailed test, and significance is inversely proportional to the P-value (ie, 1 - P-value). YES affirms P-value < Alpha and is therefore significantly different (ie,. the likelihood that an observed difference is a real effect and not due to random chance, or the likelihood that the particle size threshold in (mm) is significantly different between survey years), and NO affirms is P-value >= Alpha and is therefore not significantly different. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 1.

Test (2) Criterion (mm), whereas the criterion is the particle size in (mm) in which to perform a 2 sample proportion test. In pebble counts, the 2 samples could be pebble counts at the same location but from different survey years, from a study reach and a reference reach, or before and after installing a restoration project. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 2.

Test (2) Tails, whereas a 1-tailed test focuses on detecting a difference in a specific direction (e.g., greater than or less than) and a two-tailed test checks for any difference, regardless of direction (e.g., not equal to). A 1-sample t-test compares a single sample's mean to a known value, and a 2-sample t-test compares the means of two independent groups. In cumulative effects analysis such as in pebble counts, a uni-directional (or one-tailed) test can be appropriate for whether the sample reach is greater than the reference reach (Ps > Pr). For example did a management action increase the fine sediment proportion of the particle size distribution? 1-tailed, uni-directional tests are more sensitive than 2-tailed, two-directional tests but do carry the danger of ignoring significant change in the opposite direction. For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 2.

Test (2) Alpha, whereas Alpha is the significance level and represents the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true, a Type 1 error (ie, a false positive, or the probability of observing a difference due to chance, or falsely concluding that there is a significant effect or difference when, actually, there is no difference). It is often set to 0.05 (ie, 5%). Alpha is related to the confidence level, which is 1 - α. For example, if Alpha α = 0.05, the confidence level is 95% (1 - 0.05 = 0.95). For multiple criterion (ie, more than one particle size threshold such as 2mm, 4mm, 8mm, etc), they must be tested individually, and this value is from Test no 2.
